dt: {bc}to have or keep a grip on
{bc}to have as a position of responsibility
{bc}to continue in the same way or state {bc}{sx|last||}

dt.t: According to the forecast, good weather will {it}hold{/it}.

dt: {bc}to have or keep possession or control of
{bc}to limit the movement or activity of {bc}{sx|restrain||}
{bc}to continue in a condition or position
{bc}to continue moving on (a course) without change
{bc}to make accept a legal or moral duty

dt.t: He is widely {it}held{/it} to be a genius.

dt: {bc}to continue to be present or exist

dt.t: My money {it}held out{/it} until I got paid.
The soldiers {it}held out{/it} until help arrived.

dt: {bc}to rob while threatening with a weapon

shortdef: to have or keep a grip on
to take in and have within : contain

dt.t: He had a tight {it}hold{/it} on the rope.

dt: {bc}a note or rest in music kept up longer than usual

shortdef: the act or way of holding : grip
a note or rest in music kept up longer than usual

dt: {bc}the part of a ship below the decks in which cargo is stored

shortdef: the part of a ship below the decks in which cargo is stored
the cargo compartment of an airplane

cxs.cxl: past tense and past participle of

dt.t: You should {it}take{/it} it by the handle.

dt: {bc}to carry or go with from one place to another

dt.t: She {it}took{/it} the book from the table.
We will {it}take{/it} a cottage by the shore for the summer.

dt: {bc}to begin to perform the responsibilities of {bc}{sx|assume||}
{bc}to use as a way of going from one place to another

dt.t: I don't have to {it}take{/it} that from you.
He {it}took{/it} my side in the argument.

dt: {bc}to find out by testing or examining

dt.t: He {it}took{/it} down every word of the speech.
I {it}took{/it} it to be the truth.
You can {it}take{/it} my word for it.
She {it}took{/it} sick just before the holiday.
I {it}took{/it} it to mean something different.
I {it}take{/it} it {it}back{/it}. I really don't hate you.

dt: {bc}to have an intended or expected result

dt.t: Wait for the medicine to {it}take effect{/it}.

dt: {bc}to assume as true, real, or expected

dt.t: The tree I planted never {it}took hold{/it}.
We {it}took in{/it} travelers for the night.
The club is not {it}taking in{/it} new members.

dt: {bc}to receive and do at home for pay

dt.t: He {it}took in{/it} the situation at a glance.
They were {it}taken in{/it} by an old trick.
I'm willing to {it}take off{/it} ten percent.

dt: {bc}to leave a surface in beginning a flight or leap
{bc}to begin (a task) or struggle against (an opponent)
{bc}to gain or show as or as if a part of oneself

dt.t: The city {it}took on{/it} a carnival mood.
The business will {it}take on{/it} more workers.

dt: {bc}to make an unusual show of grief or anger
{bc}to do or join in something together with others

dt.t: We'll {it}take up{/it} a collection for the gift.

dt: {bc}to start something for the first time or after a pause

dt.t: Our class {it}took up{/it} the lesson where we left off.

dt: {bc}to change by making tighter or shorter

dt.t: She needs to {it}take up{/it} the dress in the back.

pt: {sc}take{/sc}, {sc}seize{/sc}, and {sc}grasp{/sc} mean to get a hold on with or as if with the hand. {sc}take{/sc} can be used of any way of getting possession or control of something.

pt.t: You {it}took{/it} more food than you can use.

pt: {sc}seize{/sc} is used for an act of taking something suddenly and by force.

pt.t: A police officer {it}seized{/it} the thief in the act of escaping.

pt: {sc}grasp{/sc} is used for taking something in the hand and keeping it there firmly.

shortdef: to carry or go with from one place to another
to have or keep a grip on
to take in and have within : contain
